formula: Zr 1.2 V 0.8 NbTi x Al y
evidence: In Zr 1.2 V 0.8 NbTi 3 Al y and Zr 1.2 V 0.8 NbTi 3.6 Al y, the increase of Al significantly strengthens the LHEA with decreasing density. By controlling the Ti and Al, the specific yield strength of Ti3.6Al0.6 LHEA was over 180 MPa m 3 /kg, combined with the ductility of ~27%.
By controlling the Ti and Al, the specific yield strength of Ti3.6Al0.6 LHEA was over 180 MPa m 3 /kg, combined with the ductility of ~27%.

The recrystallized Ti2Al0.3, Ti3.6Al0.3, and Ti3.6Al0.6 show outstanding tensile strength-ductility matching: the yield stresses of recrystallized Ti2Al0.3, Ti3.6Al0.3, and Ti3.6Al0.6 were ~850 MPa, ~1000 MPa, and ~1100 MPa, respectively; and the fracture strains were all over 25%.

The recrystallized Ti2Al0.3, Ti3.6Al0.3, and Ti3.6Al0.6 show outstanding tensile strength-ductility matching: the yield stresses of recrystallized Ti2Al0.3, Ti3.6Al0.3, and Ti3.6Al0.6 were ~850 MPa, ~1000 MPa, and ~1100 MPa, respectively; and the fracture strains were all over 25%.

The recrystallized Ti2Al0.3, Ti3.6Al0.3, and Ti3.6Al0.6 show outstanding tensile strength-ductility matching: the yield stresses of recrystallized Ti2Al0.3, Ti3.6Al0.3, and Ti3.6Al0.6 were ~850 MPa, ~1000 MPa, and ~1100 MPa, respectively; and the fracture strains were all over 25%.

The previous studies  [20] [21] [22] 31]  show that the intermetallic phases usually limit the mechanical properties of LHEAs. In our work, by controlling Ti and Al, the B2 phase and C14 Laves phase were successfully suppressed, causing outstanding tensile strength-ductility matching with relatively low density.

formula: Zr 1.2 V 0.8 NbTi x Al y
evidence: In this work, we reported a series of Zr 1.2 V 0.8 NbTi x Al y lightweight HEAs (TixAly LHEAs) with outstanding specific yield strength-ductility matching. By controlling the contents of Ti and Al, the lattice distortion and mixing enthalpy of the LHEAs can be effectively adjusted, which suppressed the precipitation formation and resulted in the single BCC structure of the TixAly LHEAs. Moreover, the adding of Ti and Al achieved the balance of density reduction and mechanical property improvement, which is considered a combination of solid solution strengthening and chemical short-range order strengthening. Finally, the specific yield strength of TixAly LHEAs is at least 40% higher than current developed HEAs with the same deformability level (tensile ductility over 25%). Our results bring new insights into the phase stability and precipitation suppression of HEAs, which is constructive for the development of novel lightweight alloy with outstanding mechanical properties.
